questions.stem: A child is diagnosed with phenylketonuria (PKU) shortly after birth through newborn screening. The parents are counseled that with strict dietary management beginning in infancy, their child can develop normally. This scenario best illustrates which principle?

options.text: Dominant-recessive inheritance determines phenotypic expression regardless of environment
Environmental intervention can modify phenotypic expression even when the genotype is fixed
Polygenic inheritance makes all genetic conditions amenable to dietary treatment
Chromosomal abnormalities can be corrected through early nutritional intervention

questions.explanation: PKU is a classic example of gene-environment interaction. The genotype (homozygous recessive for the PKU allele) is fixed, but the phenotype (intellectual disability) can be prevented by modifying the environment (restricting phenylalanine in the diet). This demonstrates that genotype does not inevitably determine phenotype when environmental triggers are removed early.

questions.stem: A pregnant woman contracts rubella during the first trimester. Her obstetrician explains that exposure during this period carries the highest risk for congenital defects. Which principle of teratology does this timing effect best illustrate?

options.text: Teratogenic effects are entirely dose-dependent and unrelated to developmental timing
Susceptibility to teratogens depends on the developmental stage at the time of exposure
All teratogens produce identical patterns of malformation regardless of timing
The fetal period is the most vulnerable to structural malformations from teratogenic exposure

questions.explanation: A core principle of teratology is that susceptibility depends on the developmental stage at the time of exposure. The embryonic period (weeks 3-8) is the most critical because organogenesis is occurring and all major organ systems are forming. Rubella exposure in the first trimester is particularly dangerous because it coincides with this period of rapid organ formation. The fetal period involves growth and refinement rather than initial formation of structures.

questions.stem: A child presents with a smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, short palpebral fissures, microcephaly, and significant cognitive deficits. The mother reports heavy alcohol consumption throughout pregnancy. This presentation is most consistent with which diagnosis?

options.text: Down syndrome
Fragile X syndrome
Fetal alcohol syndrome
Turner syndrome

questions.explanation: Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is characterized by a triad of facial dysmorphology (smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, short palpebral fissures), growth retardation, and central nervous system dysfunction including intellectual disability. FAS is the most severe manifestation within the Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD) continuum and is the leading known preventable cause of intellectual disability in the Western world.

questions.stem: A neonate receives Apgar scores of 3 at 1 minute and 7 at 5 minutes after birth. Which interpretation of these scores is most accurate?

options.text: The 1-minute score is a stronger predictor of long-term outcomes than the 5-minute score
The low initial score indicated critical need for immediate intervention, while improvement to 7 suggests adequate response to resuscitation
Both scores indicate the neonate is in good condition and no intervention is needed
The discrepancy between scores suggests scoring error and reassessment is needed

questions.explanation: Apgar scores of 0-3 indicate a critical need for resuscitation. The improvement from 3 to 7 suggests the infant responded well to intervention. Scores of 7-10 indicate good condition. The 5-minute Apgar score is the stronger predictor of long-term developmental outcomes, not the 1-minute score. The 1-minute score primarily guides immediate clinical decision-making.

questions.stem: A genetic counselor explains to prospective parents that the risk of Down syndrome increases significantly with maternal age, rising from approximately 1 in 1,250 at age 25 to 1 in 100 at age 40. Down syndrome results from which chromosomal abnormality?

options.text: A mutation in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome
An extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21)
A missing X chromosome (45,X karyotype)
An extra X chromosome in males (47,XXY karyotype)

questions.explanation: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy 21, the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is the most common chromosomal abnormality, and its incidence increases with maternal age due to age-related changes in oocyte quality. FMR1 gene mutation causes Fragile X syndrome. A missing X chromosome (45,X) causes Turner syndrome. An extra X chromosome in males (47,XXY) causes Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.stem: A developmental psychologist is reviewing the three stages of prenatal development. Which of the following statements are accurate? Select all that apply.

options.text: The germinal period spans from fertilization through implantation in the uterine wall
The embryonic period (weeks 3-8) is when all major organ systems begin to form through organogenesis
The fetal period is the most vulnerable to structural birth defects from teratogenic exposure
Approximately 50-60% of fertilized ova fail to implant successfully during the germinal period
The neural tube closes during the fetal period around week 12

questions.explanation: The germinal period (weeks 0-2) extends from fertilization through implantation, with 50-60% of fertilized ova failing to implant. The embryonic period (weeks 3-8) is when organogenesis occurs and is the most vulnerable to teratogens (not the fetal period). The neural tube closes by approximately day 28 (during the embryonic period, not the fetal period at week 12). The fetal period involves growth and refinement of already-formed structures.

questions.stem: A pediatric neurologist is evaluating a 14-month-old infant. Which of the following neonatal reflexes should have already disappeared by this age? Select all that apply.

options.text: Rooting reflex (disappears by 3-4 months)
Moro (startle) reflex (disappears by 5-6 months)
Babinski reflex (disappears by 8-12 months)
Palmar grasp reflex (disappears by 3-4 months)
Voluntary reaching (a permanent motor skill)

questions.explanation: By 14 months, all primitive reflexes should have disappeared: rooting (3-4 months), palmar grasp (3-4 months), Moro (5-6 months), and Babinski (8-12 months). Voluntary reaching is not a primitive reflex but a developing motor skill that persists throughout life. Persistence of primitive reflexes beyond their expected disappearance may indicate neurological concern.

questions.stem: A clinician is gathering a comprehensive developmental history for a child presenting with learning difficulties. Which prenatal factors should the clinician inquire about? Select all that apply.

options.text: Maternal alcohol and substance use during pregnancy
Maternal infections during pregnancy (TORCH infections)
Maternal nutrition and folic acid supplementation
Chronic maternal stress and cortisol exposure
The child's current dietary habits

questions.explanation: A comprehensive prenatal history should include substance use (associated with FASD and other effects), maternal infections (TORCH infections can cause cognitive impairment), nutrition (folic acid prevents neural tube defects; malnutrition affects brain development), and maternal stress (elevated cortisol can affect fetal HPA axis development). The child's current dietary habits, while important for overall health, are not a prenatal factor.

questions.stem: A genetics textbook discusses patterns of inheritance relevant to psychological disorders and conditions. Which of the following are accurately described? Select all that apply.

options.text: Huntington's disease follows a dominant inheritance pattern, requiring only one copy of the allele for expression
Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disorder requiring two copies of the recessive allele
Intelligence and temperament are examples of polygenic traits influenced by many genes
Fragile X syndrome is caused by a mutation on the Y chromosome
Codominance occurs when both alleles are fully expressed, as seen in AB blood type

questions.explanation: Huntington's disease is autosomal dominant (one allele sufficient). PKU is autosomal recessive (two copies needed). Intelligence and temperament are polygenic traits influenced by many genes. Fragile X syndrome is caused by a mutation on the X chromosome (not Y), specifically the FMR1 gene. Codominance means both alleles are fully expressed, as in AB blood type.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements about the TORCH infections are accurate? Select all that apply.

options.text: Rubella is especially dangerous in the first trimester and can cause deafness, heart defects, and cataracts
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common congenital viral infection and can cause hearing loss
The 'O' in TORCH stands for 'Other' infections including syphilis, varicella, and HIV
Herpes simplex poses the greatest risk during the second trimester rather than at delivery
Toxoplasmosis can cause brain damage, visual impairment, and intellectual disability in the fetus

questions.explanation: Rubella in the first trimester can cause deafness, heart defects, cataracts, and intellectual disability. CMV is indeed the most common congenital viral infection, associated with hearing loss and intellectual disability. 'O' stands for Other infections including syphilis, varicella, and HIV. Herpes simplex risk is highest during vaginal delivery with active lesions, not during the second trimester. Toxoplasmosis can cause brain damage, visual impairment, and intellectual disability.

questions.stem: Match each chromosomal abnormality with its correct chromosomal basis.

columns.text: FMR1 gene mutation on X chromosome

questions.explanation: Down syndrome results from trisomy 21 (extra chromosome 21). Turner syndrome occurs in females with a missing X chromosome (45,X), characterized by short stature and infertility. Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with an extra X chromosome (47,XXY), characterized by tall stature and reduced fertility. Fragile X syndrome results from a mutation in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome and is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability.

questions.stem: Match each neonatal reflex with the stimulus that elicits it.

columns.text: Stroke cheek or corner of mouth
Sudden loud noise or loss of support
Object placed in palm of hand

questions.explanation: Rooting reflex is elicited by stroking the cheek or corner of the mouth, causing the head to turn toward the stimulus. The Moro reflex is triggered by a sudden loud noise or loss of support, producing extension then retraction of the arms. The Babinski reflex is elicited by stroking the sole of the foot, causing the toes to fan out. The palmar grasp is triggered by placing an object in the palm, causing the fingers to close around it.

questions.stem: For each prenatal period, select ALL characteristics or events that apply.

columns.text: Most vulnerable to structural birth defects
Rapid synapse formation and myelination begin
All major organ systems begin forming

questions.explanation: The germinal period involves implantation of the blastocyst in the uterine wall. The embryonic period is when organogenesis occurs (all major organ systems begin forming) and is the most vulnerable to structural birth defects. The third trimester involves rapid brain development with extensive synapse formation and the beginnings of myelination. The fetal period overall involves growth and refinement rather than initial organ formation.

questions.stem: For each teratogen or prenatal risk factor, select ALL associated outcomes.
questions.explanation: Heavy prenatal alcohol exposure causes FAS, characterized by facial dysmorphology (smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, short palpebral fissures) and growth retardation (low birth weight). Tobacco is associated with low birth weight and preterm delivery. Rubella in the first trimester causes deafness, heart defects, cataracts, and intellectual disability. Folic acid deficiency is associated with neural tube defects (spina bifida, anencephaly).

questions.stem: The Apgar score assesses five criteria at 1 and 5 minutes after birth. The 'A' stands for {{blank1}}, 'P' stands for {{blank2}}, 'G' stands for {{blank3}}, and the second 'A' stands for {{blank4}}. Each criterion is scored 0-2, with a total possible score of 10.

options.text: Appearance (skin color)
Activity (muscle tone)
Alertness (consciousness level)
Airway (breathing pattern)
Posture (body position)
Pulse (heart rate)
Pupil response (neurological)
Pain response (sensory)
Growth (body weight)
Grasp (reflex strength)
Grimace (reflex irritability)
Gait (movement quality)
Appearance (skin color)
Alertness (consciousness)
Auditory response (hearing)
Activity (muscle tone)

questions.explanation: The Apgar scoring system uses the acronym: Appearance (skin color), Pulse (heart rate), Grimace (reflex irritability), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiration. Each criterion is scored 0-2, for a total of 0-10. Scores of 7-10 indicate good condition, 4-6 require some intervention, and 0-3 indicate critical need for resuscitation. The 5-minute score is more predictive of long-term outcomes.

questions.stem: During prenatal development, the three germ layers differentiate into specialized tissues. The {{blank1}} gives rise to the nervous system and skin. The {{blank2}} develops into muscles, bones, and the circulatory system. The endoderm forms the {{blank3}} systems. The neural tube, which becomes the brain and spinal cord, closes by approximately {{blank4}}.

options.text: ectoderm
mesoderm
endoderm
trophoblast
ectoderm
mesoderm
endoderm
blastocyst
nervous and integumentary
muscular and skeletal
digestive and respiratory
circulatory and lymphatic
day 14 of gestation
day 28 of gestation
week 12 of gestation
week 20 of gestation

questions.explanation: The ectoderm differentiates into the nervous system and skin. The mesoderm forms muscles, bones, and the circulatory system. The endoderm gives rise to the digestive and respiratory systems. The neural tube closes by approximately day 28 of gestation, which is why folic acid supplementation before and during early pregnancy is critical for preventing neural tube defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old child is referred for evaluation of learning difficulties. The child has a smooth philtrum, thin vermilion border, short palpebral fissures, and microcephaly. The biological mother reportedly consumed alcohol heavily throughout pregnancy.

options.text: Characteristic facial dysmorphology (smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, short palpebral fissures)
Documented heavy prenatal alcohol exposure
Extra chromosome visible on karyotype
Family history of autosomal dominant inheritance pattern
Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS)
Down syndrome
Fragile X syndrome
Intellectual disability and learning difficulties across academic domains
Behavioral and attention problems commonly co-occurring
Normal cognitive development with physical growth delay only
Progressive neurological deterioration over time

questions.explanation: The diagnostic features of FAS include characteristic facial dysmorphology and documented prenatal alcohol exposure. FAS is the most severe form of FASD and involves intellectual disability, learning difficulties, and frequently co-occurring behavioral and attention problems. FAS does not involve progressive deterioration; rather, the deficits are stable but may become more apparent as academic demands increase.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old pregnant woman undergoes prenatal genetic counseling. She is concerned about the increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities associated with advanced maternal age.

options.text: Age-related changes in oocyte quality increasing nondisjunction risk
Maternal age of 35 or older at delivery classified as advanced maternal age
Paternal age as the primary determinant of chromosomal abnormality risk
Maternal substance use as the sole contributor to genetic risk
Elevated risk of trisomy conditions, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21)
Elevated risk of autosomal recessive metabolic disorders
Elevated risk of X-linked genetic conditions
Prenatal genetic screening and diagnostic testing should be offered
Discussion of the specific risk statistics for Down syndrome at her age
Recommendation to terminate the pregnancy based on age alone
Reassurance that advanced maternal age carries no increased genetic risks

questions.explanation: Advanced maternal age (35+) is associated with increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly trisomy conditions like Down syndrome, due to age-related changes in oocyte quality that increase nondisjunction risk. Appropriate clinical responses include offering prenatal genetic screening/diagnostic testing and discussing specific risk statistics. Maternal age effects are distinct from autosomal recessive conditions (which depend on carrier status) and X-linked conditions (which depend on maternal carrier status regardless of age).

questions.stem: A student is studying teratogen principles for the EPPP. Highlight ALL statements that are accurate.
questions.passage: Teratogens produce identical effects regardless of the timing of exposure during pregnancy. [Susceptibility to teratogens depends on the developmental stage at the time of exposure, with organ systems most vulnerable during their period of most rapid formation]. The fetal period (weeks 9-birth) is the most critical for structural malformations. [The embryonic period (weeks 3-8) is the most critical for structural malformations because organogenesis occurs during this time]. All teratogenic effects are immediately apparent at birth. [The effects of prenatal substance exposure may not be fully apparent at birth but can emerge as developmental delays during childhood]. Teratogenic effects are dose-dependent, with greater exposure typically producing more severe effects. [The genotype of both the mother and the embryo/fetus influences susceptibility to teratogenic effects]. All pregnant women exposed to the same teratogen will have identical outcomes.

highlightableSegments.text: Susceptibility to teratogens depends on the developmental stage at the time of exposure, with organ systems most vulnerable during their period of most rapid formation
The embryonic period (weeks 3-8) is the most critical for structural malformations because organogenesis occurs during this time
The effects of prenatal substance exposure may not be fully apparent at birth but can emerge as developmental delays during childhood
The genotype of both the mother and the embryo/fetus influences susceptibility to teratogenic effects

questions.explanation: All four bracketed statements are accurate teratogenic principles. Susceptibility depends on developmental timing. The embryonic period is the most vulnerable for structural malformations. Effects may not be apparent at birth but emerge later. Genetic susceptibility of both mother and fetus influences outcomes. The unbracketed incorrect statements claim teratogens have identical effects regardless of timing, that the fetal period is most critical for structural defects, and that all women have identical outcomes.

questions.stem: A medical student is reviewing chromosomal abnormalities for an exam. Highlight ALL accurate statements.
questions.passage: Down syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 21 and its incidence decreases with maternal age. [Down syndrome results from trisomy 21 (an extra copy of chromosome 21) and its incidence increases with maternal age]. Turner syndrome affects males who have an extra Y chromosome. [Turner syndrome (45,X) affects females who are missing one X chromosome, resulting in short stature and infertility]. Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and results from a mutation in the FMR1 gene. [Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) involves an extra X chromosome in males and is associated with tall stature and possible language difficulties]. Fragile X syndrome tends to be more severe in females due to their having two X chromosomes. [Fragile X syndrome is more severe in males because they have only one X chromosome, so the mutation has a greater effect without a compensating normal copy].

highlightableSegments.text: Down syndrome results from trisomy 21 (an extra copy of chromosome 21) and its incidence increases with maternal age
Turner syndrome (45,X) affects females who are missing one X chromosome, resulting in short stature and infertility
Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) involves an extra X chromosome in males and is associated with tall stature and possible language difficulties
Fragile X syndrome is more severe in males because they have only one X chromosome, so the mutation has a greater effect without a compensating normal copy

questions.explanation: All four bracketed statements are accurate. Down syndrome is trisomy 21, increasing with maternal age. Turner syndrome (45,X) affects females with a missing X chromosome. Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) affects males with an extra X. Fragile X is more severe in males because they lack a second, potentially normal X chromosome to compensate. The unbracketed incorrect statements contain reversed or inaccurate information.

questions.stem: Arrange the stages of prenatal development and neonatal events in the correct chronological order.

items.text: Fertilization of ovum, forming a zygote with 46 chromosomes
Cell division and implantation of blastocyst in uterine wall (germinal period)
Neural tube closure and beginning of organogenesis (embryonic period)
Age of viability approached as organ systems mature (weeks 22-26)
Rapid synapse formation and myelination begin (third trimester)
Apgar scoring at 1 and 5 minutes after birth

questions.explanation: Prenatal development proceeds: (1) Fertilization creates the zygote. (2) During the germinal period, the zygote divides and the blastocyst implants. (3) The embryonic period involves neural tube closure (~day 28) and organogenesis. (4) During the fetal period, the age of viability is reached around weeks 22-26. (5) The third trimester brings rapid brain development with synaptogenesis and myelination. (6) After birth, Apgar scoring assesses the neonate at 1 and 5 minutes.

questions.stem: Arrange the disappearance of neonatal reflexes in chronological order from earliest to latest.

items.text: Stepping reflex disappears (~2-3 months)
Rooting and palmar grasp reflexes disappear (~3-4 months)
Sucking reflex becomes voluntary (~4 months)
Moro (startle) reflex disappears (~5-6 months)
Babinski reflex disappears (~8-12 months)

questions.explanation: Neonatal reflexes disappear in a predictable sequence as the nervous system matures: Stepping reflex (~2-3 months), rooting and palmar grasp (~3-4 months), sucking becomes voluntary (~4 months), Moro reflex (~5-6 months), and Babinski (~8-12 months). Persistence of any reflex beyond its expected disappearance may indicate neurological concern and warrants further evaluation.

questions.stem: A genetic counselor reviews data on the relationship between maternal age and the incidence of Down syndrome (trisomy 21).
questions.question: What pattern does this data reveal about the relationship between maternal age and Down syndrome risk?

options.text: Risk remains constant across all maternal ages
Risk increases linearly with each year of maternal age
Risk increases exponentially after approximately age 35, reflecting accelerated age-related changes in oocyte quality
Risk peaks at age 30 and then declines in older mothers

questions.explanation: The data show that Down syndrome incidence remains relatively stable from age 20-30, then increases exponentially from age 35 onward (from approximately 1 in 345 at age 30 to 1 in 100 at age 40 to 1 in 30 at age 45). This exponential increase reflects age-related deterioration in oocyte quality, leading to increased risk of nondisjunction during meiosis. This pattern is why age 35 is commonly used as a clinical threshold for offering additional prenatal genetic testing.

questions.stem: A researcher tracks teratogenic vulnerability across the three stages of prenatal development, measuring the relative risk of major structural malformations at each stage.
questions.question: What do these data reveal about the relationship between timing of exposure and type of teratogenic effect?

options.text: Both structural and functional risks are highest during the germinal period
Structural malformation risk peaks during the embryonic period while functional/behavioral effects become more prominent during the fetal period
All teratogenic risks are uniformly distributed across prenatal development
The fetal period carries the highest risk for both structural and functional defects

questions.explanation: The data illustrate a key teratogenic principle: structural malformation risk peaks during the embryonic period (weeks 3-8) when organogenesis is occurring, while functional and behavioral effects become more prominent during the fetal period when the brain and other systems are being refined. During the germinal period, exposure typically results in embryonic loss rather than malformation. This pattern underscores why timing of exposure is critical for predicting the type of teratogenic effect.

questions.stem: Categorize each prenatal characteristic or event into its correct developmental period.

items.text: Rapid cell division (cleavage) and formation of blastocyst
Neural tube closure by approximately day 28
Age of viability reached around weeks 22-26
Implantation of the developing organism in the uterine wall
Differentiation of ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm germ layers
Extensive synapse formation and beginning of myelination
All major organ systems begin to form (organogenesis)

questions.explanation: Germinal period (weeks 0-2): Cell division/cleavage and implantation. Embryonic period (weeks 3-8): Neural tube closure (~day 28), germ layer differentiation, and organogenesis. Fetal period (weeks 9-birth): Age of viability (~weeks 22-26) and extensive synaptogenesis and myelination (especially third trimester).

questions.stem: Categorize each genetic condition by its inheritance pattern.

items.text: Huntington's disease: Single dominant allele sufficient for expression
Phenylketonuria (PKU): Requires two copies of the recessive allele
Down syndrome: Extra copy of chromosome 21
Cystic fibrosis: Requires homozygous recessive genotype
Turner syndrome: Missing X chromosome (45,X karyotype)
Klinefelter syndrome: Extra X chromosome in males (47,XXY)

questions.explanation: Autosomal dominant: Huntington's disease (one copy of the dominant allele is sufficient). Autosomal recessive: PKU and cystic fibrosis (both require two copies of the recessive allele). Chromosomal abnormalities: Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Turner syndrome (45,X), and Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) involve numerical or structural changes in chromosomes rather than single-gene inheritance patterns.
